I, on the other hand, had an overdone steak on a hard bun (not toasted, hard), with a chunk of bone that was nearly 1/3 the total size of the steak. Biting into that was an unpleasant surprise. It came with a nicely dressed arugula salad. In the meantime, Mr J ordered a "waiter's choice" gin cocktail that was, frankly, not very well made. It was a rifff on a Moscow Mule, but it jsut didn't turn out very well. I'd ordered the Founders Oatmeal stout which was exactly what one would expect. Our server, who had ONE other table checked on us 0 times. Mr J did mention to our unnamed server that his cocktail was underwhelming, and he took off 50% of the cost.  Overall, the good parts were good, the bad parts were bad, and it seemed as if the whole thing jsut missed the mark. Since we'd heard great things about this place from others and it was kind of close to getting it right,  this left us thinking that we'd maybe give the place another shot...sometime...not too soon. We exited through the wine shop, and ran into Christopher (whom we later found was the grandson of the original Glunz) who invited us to try the wines opened for the earlier tasting. It happened we found one we quite liked and was quite charming, as he's always been whenever I've been in shopping. He asked us how we liked the meal and we sort of hemmed and hawed and eventually gave him an abbreviated and hopefully less stinging review than the one above.   He then apologized profusely, thanked us for our honesty, and explained that the day before, on a Saturday, their head chef just walked out.  Just like that, left them high and dry and they had been scrambling through the Saturday dinner service and Sunday brunch with the sous-chef and staff trying to work out how to run things. This definitely explained the mis-steps we'd experienced, and I don't think he could have been more genuine in his explanation. I completely understand-sometimes someone just puts the screws to you. We also said we were happy to come again and figured we'd just hit a bad time. He then generously simply GAVE us the bottle of wine were intended to purchase, which more than smoothed over my dissatisfaction. During the conversation, we started talking gin drinks, and ended up purchasing a bottle of nice gin too. So, not the best experience, but I understand they'd hit a rough patch, and the problems all seem minor and fixable, and we look forward to returning.

8.description: Our experience here was a wild ride from start to finish.First, (after seating ourselves) our waiter eventually came over, but was completely confused. He didn't understand the meals that we were trying to order (it seemed like he didn't even understand the menu itself), and then simply walked away after taking our order (which were burgers - he didn't bother to ask how we wanted them) without removing our menus. After about 10 minutes of waiting with no drinks or any other service, we finally had to ask for water. Which he brought over in paper disposable cups. Like something from a fast-food restaurant. Eventually the manager came over and saw how strange our service was, so she replaced our cups with actual glasses with ice water and tried to apologize. Then the meal came. Luckily, the burgers were very, very good. However, they were supposed to come with a side of fries which were forgotten, except when we finally got these fries (after we had finished the burgers), they were half-raw and tasted rubbery. All in all, this was a very strange meal. I see all these positive reviews, but our experience was completely different from them.

31.description: My new favorite bar in the city!New favorite bar is an understatement -- the service and drinks were great. Super nice people and I will be back quite often. The staff here really go out of their way to make sure patrons enjoy their visit here. I didn't eat anything while here, but next time will definitely sample the food.

34.description: This place is great and serves one of the best burgers I've ever had.  Order it medium rare and wash it down with a liter of German beer.

16.description: A friend and I were looking for a bar to watch the Bears game on Sunday but less crowded and we stumbled upon Glunz Tavern. As I debated on hair of the dog, I watched Daren the bartender make a few bloody marys and his attention to detail convinced me to order one. The drink went great with the HUGE pretzel and the eggs benedict my friend and I shared. I enjoyed this place because the staff was welcoming and the history of the tavern is great. The Glunz Tavern was established in 1888, closed during prohibition for 90 some years and reopened in 2012. The tin ceiling, wooden floors, and bar are the original. There are other tales Daren can share so I won't take all of his stories. I went back to Glunz for dinner and to my surprise they have live music on Wednesday evenings starting at 7:30 pm. The ambiance, candle light, and music made for an unintended but very nice romantic dinner. We ordered gnocchi without the corned beef, Schnitzel, and pretzel bread pudding. Daren came to the rescue once again. Since they did not have the Chianti Classico I wanted he offered another great red. They have a very wide selection of spirits since The House of Glunz is attached to the tavern and you can just walk over to browse the store. Great place for food, drinks, and good company.

13.description: This place deserves the highest review that I could possibly leave. The night I came was a little unique (which made my experience probably more memorable than others might be), but throughout it all, the quality of the service, the food, and the atmosphere all deserved 5 stars.Highlights: they have a great wine shop (with a super helpful staff), let you try beers before you take your pick, have an excellent and delicious menu, and are overall very attentive!First, as we wandered in on a Wednesday evening before a Second City show, we were told that the dining area was reserved for a special event, but the bar and some tall tables around the bar were available. We took a tall table, which was situated right next to the dining area. and asked our exceptional waiter about what was going on. It was an Austrian wine night, so they had an Austrian wine expert come in, talk about 5 different wines which people got to try, and had a special multiple course dinner to go along with the wines. We were close enough to hear the first talk by the expert (which we super enjoyed), and our waiter showed us the wines and menu they were eating. We asked if there was extra of the entree they were having, and while our waiter checked with the chef, we wandered into the wine shop (the oldest continuously running wine shop in the country... I think they said!). While the lady in the wine shop was showing us around, answering all our questions (and even letting us try some of the wine that was open), the chef came out personally to let us know the status of our dinner (since we wanted to special order what the Austrian wine lovers were eating).I won't keep this saga going forever, but essentially we got everything we wanted and more, with the help of an amazing crew! Thank you!

11.description: Drinks = top notch!Our server took us both on a wonderful libation journey that included Sazerac, Horse's Neck, The Bronx Cocktail, and Champs Elysee. Oh - and then M ordered a bottle of wine. She drank half of it, recorked it, and brought it home.And I loved our server. He was perfectly charming, flirtatious, and gosh darn easy on the eyes. He was adept at choosing my drinks and helping me narrow my food options. He was initially very attentive but that TLC waned as the tavern became busier.The food was good. M absolutely loved loved LOVED it. I just thought it was okay. We got charcuterie, pretzel, deviled eggs, and gnocchi. I tried all of the charcuterie nibbles and then let M conquer it all. We decided that the pretzel was just a means of delivery for the scrumptious mustard dipping sauce. I liked the deviled eggs and M wasn't as much of a fan. I thought the gnocchi was good but too salty whereas M was completely blown away and said it was even better than what was served at the now closed Maison Brasserie.Our bill with tip came to about $175.We really liked the old school spirit of The Glunz Tavern. Besides the one flat screen television by the bar (and it was turned off the whole time) everything else about the place was old. Like, antique and not worn down or out dated. It's a family business and there were members of the Glunz family working that evening. Besides the girl who toppled her stool and fell on the floor the place was quiet. Not awkwardly quiet or anything like that. It was just good for conversation and being chill. We'll go again and definitely when we want to unwind.

39.description: Limited menu, but what they do is good German fare. Deviled eggs and huge pretzel are great appetizers to share. Schnitzel and Riesling chicken were tasty, generous portions. Outdoor seating, without an obnoxious sports-bar crowd, makes for a relaxing experience on Wells.

37.description: Gorgeous decor. And most of it is borrowed from classic Chicago establishments.  The large mirror hails from the Pump Room.  And the bar is from the Ambassador West hotel.  Original tray ceilings.  The owner was all too eager to tell us they're were the first location to bottle Schlitz beer outside of the brewery.  Cool backstory.  This is a GREAT place to sip and enjoy classic cocktails.  The Old Fashioned is reportedly a favorite but I opted for the bourbon cocktail whose name escapes me (guess I had too many).  Great place.

0.description: Glunz Tavern has been a favorite place of my husband and mine as we live around the corner, both love Bavarian food and enjoy a strong old fashion (got to love those brandied cherries!). In turn, when we were planning for our rehearsal dinner, this was the first place on our list.Our wedding was on New Years Eve (Thursday), so we inquired about renting out the restaurant on Wednesday (something they normally only do on Mondays), and Barbara (the owner) happily obliged. The planning process with Barbara was both extremely fun and easy. We tried pretty much all the food and a bunch of wine and settled on a set menu of deviled eggs, the class of titans and large German pretzels for appetizers, corned beef gnocchi, cheeseburger or salmon for mains and the tavern sunday or nutella crepes for dessert. We chose an assortment of red, white and bubbly and had our two signature cocktails -- old fashion and glogg as part of our open bar with draft beer. To be honest, we were more excited about our rehearsal dinner food than our wedding food since it struck a cord in both of us as the type of food our families grew up making. The evening of our rehearsal dinner went off without a hitch! Everyone loved the food and drinks and the beautifully ornate and historical atmosphere. Barbara and family even opened up the private tasting room for us to use after the House of Glunz (the wine shop attached to it) closed. I would without a doubt recommend Glunz Tavern for everything from a good glass of wine or strong old fashioned, to an intimate dinner, to a larger event or private party. Thank you again, Barbara!

38.description: This is a very fun place to have some drinks and food with friends. Their food is top notch and their drink menu is built to pair with their food perfectly.  The service staff is attentive and are great at making useful and relevant suggestions.  They're well trained and cover for each other well.  I highly recommend their pretzel with the dunkel beer!

51.description: Not a good place for vegetarians. Food was greasy and portions are way too small and expensive. Ambiance is nice and service is good tho.

27.description: I went to Glunz Tavern for a cocktail.  My friend and I both ordered a drink off of their drink menu.  I ordered an old fashioned.  I watched the bartender carefully measure the shot and a half of bourbon into the glass.  This made for an extremely weak drink.  I feel ripped off for paying $12 for this cocktail.  Between parking, 2 cocktails and tip, we spent about $35!  No thanks Glunz Tavern!  There are way better places to get a cocktail.  I definitely will not be going back.

32.description: Best chill atmosphere in old town - hands down and for that it gets extra points.  I've been here many times and the menu seems hit or miss.  (I've had the gnocchi and it was outstanding, but the beet salad was maybe 20% beets and the burger - which apparently Glunz does well - was requested to be pink in the middle - and it was, but it was charred on the outside as was the bun.)  They have a decent enough selection of beers, but it wouldn't hurt if they added a few additional ones in the mix.   Ohhh yeah - if you told me one of the the wait staff was a serial killer I'd have trouble narrowing it down as to which one it could be.  Just saying - this place has character.

54.description: This place is as good as it gets in Old Town. The Glunz Tavern maintains class, respectability, and quality without pretension. The interior is warm and inviting. The bartenders are extremely knowledgable, hilarious, and professional. Unlike many of the other restaurants and bars on Wells in Old Town, the price of food and drink actually reflect the quality and portion of what you get as opposed to the typical slop that many restaurants pass off as food at a cost of $14-$20 per. We ordered the charcuterie plate, glunz tavern salad, gnocchi, and schnitzel. All dishes were excellent. As for drinks, they make a great Old Fashioned. Make sure to ask for it with Bulleit Rye as opposed to regular Bulleit. This is a great date place too. The atmosphere can be intimate, warm, and perfect if you are trying to get to know someone. Added bonus, I didn't see a single "bro" in there. Just regular guys and gals politely and tastefully having a good time.

48.description: I met with a coworker for dinner, drinks, and non-work conversations. Two out of three isn't bad because we ended up talking about work 80% of the time. Anyway, I've been wanting try this place after seeing it on my way out of Plum Market. My coworker had never heard of it. It was great place for a last minute decision and for not having reservations on a Friday night. I can't say that happens all the time, but it was just our luck. We started off with the cheese platter and the french fries. My friend also got an order of the pretzel, which was bigger than the ones you get at a sporting event. In fact on our check, it even said "pretzel, huge". Insert your jokes here. For my entree, I ordered the gnocchi with roast beef and egg. I've been on this kick lately for ordering a meal with an egg - not sure what that's about. It wasn't a big portion (think small plates) but after chowing down on the fries and cheese and downing a glass of Malbec, I wasn't too disappointed in it. I enjoyed it and probably would get it again. Also, the entrance is right before the liquor store (if you're facing north) next door. I walked past it thinking it was part of the dining area and not the actual entry door. Duh.

44.description: If you want to experience Chicago, this is the place!!  Glunz is not a sports bar (the one TV at the bar has the volume and brightness down).  Glunz does not look modern on the inside (no neon signs).  But Glunz is 125 years old, and in that time has built up more charm and style than any chain could *ever* hope to have!  Our waiter knew the history of the place even though he's been there less than a year.  He was also better informed about the menu (pre-prohibition era drinks, wine, and food) than some professors I've had.  Most importantly he was FUN!!!  The staff at Glunz will be subdued if you want subdued.  But joke with them and they roll with it and then some.  When a repeat customer walks in, they're greeted warmly but not at the expense of other guests.  No one puts on airs - everyone is welcome.  This isn't a place looking to cater to the trends, it's a place looking to please it's extremely varied customer base.And the FOOD is AWESOME!!  The hot pretzel appetizer is big enough for three to share!!  The fish and chips special I had was the best I'd had anywhere (and that's quite a feat)!  The chicken was juicy and flavorful.  The cheese board had great range.  Lastly, the apple strudel was phenomenal!We'll be going back!!!!  Here's to another 125 years!!!!!

24.description: A friend and I were looking for a bar to watch the Bears game on Sunday but less crowded and we stumbled upon Glunz Tavern. As I debated on hair of the dog, I watched Daren the bartender make a few bloody marys and his attention to detail convinced me to order one. The drink went great with the HUGE pretzel and the eggs benedict my friend and I shared. I enjoyed this place because the staff was welcoming and the history of the tavern is great. The Glunz Tavern was established in 1888, closed during prohibition for 90 some years and reopened in 2012. The tin ceiling, wooden floors, and bar are the original. There are other tales Daren can share so I won't take all of his stories. I went back to Glunz for dinner and to my surprise they have live music on Wednesday evenings starting at 7:30 pm. The ambiance, candle light, and music made for an unintended but very nice romantic dinner. We ordered gnocchi without the corned beef, Schnitzel, and pretzel bread pudding. Daren came to the rescue once again. Since they did not have the Chianti Classico I wanted he offered another great red. They have a very wide selection of spirits since The House of Glunz is attached to the tavern and you can just walk over to browse the store. Great place for food, drinks, and good company.

7.description: Came here on a Wed night for HH with coworkers and stayed from 5:30-7:30. The beginning of our night here was positive. Good selection of wine, hard liquor, and some beers on draft, though on the pricier side. Same for food. Overall, not bad and the waitress was attentive. Around 7:00, a live band set up by the door and played ear blasting jazz. While it's nice to have live music, it's wayyyyy to early to start blasting it at 7 pm on a wed night with only a handful of patrons to play to. It became so loud that we couldn't even hear the person across from us and we decided that it was high time to leave, even with unfinished drinks. I recommend lowering the volume of the band or playing much later when people are ready to just sit back and enjoy the music. Instead we left expensive drinks unfinished in our hurry to escape to a quieter bar.

49.description: Have been to The Glunz Tavern 3 times in the last 4 months.  I can't say a bad word about the place.  Beer and wine selection is great.  Bartenders and staff excellent.  Burger and brussel sprouts are the best!  Not kidding!  Can't wait to try all the other entrees.  Smallish menu, which is always nice, since you know everything will be tasty.  Highly recommend.

40.description: Wonderful!  Delicious food - I'm so glad I found this place, I can't wait to go back and get a another HUGE pretzel.

53.description: I came here a few months ago with a group of four. It was a Tuesday and they have half price bottles of wine! I had the Thüringer and Smoked Thüringer which came with sauerkraut and potatoes. Simple dish that was plated well and very tasty. The others had duck or the schnitzel and all enjoyed. Service was good. An enjoyable night.

30.description: I want to give more stars, but my Old Fashion was weak and I needed a strong one and the beet salad did not have Arugula or much taste. Burger was Awesome though .  Fries were good , but nothing to write home about. Server was very nice. So... I would go back, but stick to wine or Beer and not get Beet Salad or Deviled Eggs.

46.description: Beautiful bar, excellent bartender.

1.description: This is really hovering around a 3.5, and I'm rounding up to be generous. I really liked this restaurant and the food... the reason it's dropped to a 3 is because our sandwiches and salads shouldn't take over an hour to come out.I got the Glunz Tavern Burger which was delicious (especially with a sunny side up egg, I'm a HUGE fan of eggs in my burgers). All in all, everyone at the table loved their food. We had everything from the crepes to the grilled cheese and the house salad. I think the grilled cheese (cheddar) was a little strong but still delicious.

55.description: I'm giving Glunz, the benefit of the doubt . . . .for while the night started very well- there were a few service hiccups along that way that put a small question mark in my mind.  So time will tell . . . .The night started off so great!  Karl, the bartender, was terrific, mixing our martinis with vigor and making sure that we were comfortable at the end of his bar.This place is lovely inside with stained glass windows, an old style wooden bar, high tops in the front windows and a small dining area in the back.  Just the kind of place you would hope to find as a neighborhood place!When it came time to eat- we were seated at a great little table right in the front window allowing us to watch the activity as Old Town came alive on this warmish night.Not sure if our table wasn't "officially" in the server's section or if he thought others were taking care of us but getting any service once we moved to the table was a bit of a challenge.  We finally flagged down Karl again and he brought us menus from behind the bar.  At that point the server came over and took our orders.  But that was the last we saw of him.  And the drink orders given to Karl were wrong.  What the heck?  And when the manager (owner?) came over and asked us how things were- we mentioned the service challenge and suddenly Karl was back in place taking care of us from behind his bar.  So I'm going to assume that Karl was our server for the remainder of this review- thus the 4 stars- for if it was for the other server- it would be less!I had the brick chicken which was quite good but my friend had the pork chop which was definitely the better of the two.  Also- we had a chance to taste the deviled eggs as well as the cheese and chacuterie plate.  While the eggs were good- the chacuterie was a bit on the slim side - definitely not anything to rave about.If you drive- street parking is pretty easy right on Wells or you can park in the new parking garage just north of the location which will run you about $14.All in all- I liked this spot to connect with friends and enjoy a drink.  But if you go- be sure to sit at the bar for Karl will take excellent care of you!

9.description: Was only there for drinks.  Nice ambiance, and some tasty beers.  Good service.

26.description: This place deserves the highest review that I could possibly leave. The night I came was a little unique (which made my experience probably more memorable than others might be), but throughout it all, the quality of the service, the food, and the atmosphere all deserved 5 stars.Highlights: they have a great wine shop (with a super helpful staff), let you try beers before you take your pick, have an excellent and delicious menu, and are overall very attentive!First, as we wandered in on a Wednesday evening before a Second City show, we were told that the dining area was reserved for a special event, but the bar and some tall tables around the bar were available. We took a tall table, which was situated right next to the dining area. and asked our exceptional waiter about what was going on. It was an Austrian wine night, so they had an Austrian wine expert come in, talk about 5 different wines which people got to try, and had a special multiple course dinner to go along with the wines. We were close enough to hear the first talk by the expert (which we super enjoyed), and our waiter showed us the wines and menu they were eating. We asked if there was extra of the entree they were having, and while our waiter checked with the chef, we wandered into the wine shop (the oldest continuously running wine shop in the country... I think they said!). While the lady in the wine shop was showing us around, answering all our questions (and even letting us try some of the wine that was open), the chef came out personally to let us know the status of our dinner (since we wanted to special order what the Austrian wine lovers were eating).I won't keep this saga going forever, but essentially we got everything we wanted and more, with the help of an amazing crew! Thank you!

25.description: In addition to being a classic, low-key gem in Chicago, this place actually serves red wine at the proper temperature.  Tired of other wine bars serving red wine at room temperature. #shutupwinesnob. What's with the music though?  Breeders.  Social Distortion. Hard punk. All for that when I go to a hipster dive bar.  Tatted up bartender using Glunz as the stage to crank her own music interests. Know your audience.

12.description: I went here for a first date one Tuesday and we had such a good time. Neither of us had been here before, but it was a convenient location to meet up. The decor and atmosphere was really nice and homey.  It was quiet, our waitress was sweet/attentive/made great suggestions and was just overall really friendly and fun. We had the pretzel, burger and creme brulee and each was really great. Would definitely come here again!

59.description: Drinks = top notch!Our server took us both on a wonderful libation journey that included Sazerac, Horse's Neck, The Bronx Cocktail, and Champs Elysee. Oh - and then M ordered a bottle of wine. She drank half of it, recorked it, and brought it home.And I loved our server. He was perfectly charming, flirtatious, and gosh darn easy on the eyes. He was adept at choosing my drinks and helping me narrow my food options. He was initially very attentive but that TLC waned as the tavern became busier.The food was good. M absolutely loved loved LOVED it. I just thought it was okay. We got charcuterie, pretzel, deviled eggs, and gnocchi. I tried all of the charcuterie nibbles and then let M conquer it all. We decided that the pretzel was just a means of delivery for the scrumptious mustard dipping sauce. I liked the deviled eggs and M wasn't as much of a fan. I thought the gnocchi was good but too salty whereas M was completely blown away and said it was even better than what was served at the now closed Maison Brasserie.Our bill with tip came to about $175.We really liked the old school spirit of The Glunz Tavern. Besides the one flat screen television by the bar (and it was turned off the whole time) everything else about the place was old. Like, antique and not worn down or out dated. It's a family business and there were members of the Glunz family working that evening. Besides the girl who toppled her stool and fell on the floor the place was quiet. Not awkwardly quiet or anything like that. It was just good for conversation and being chill. We'll go again and definitely when we want to unwind.

21.description: How did I not know this existed?  Glunz Tavern is such a gem in the neighborhood!  I held a private event in the tasting room behind the wine shop, and everything was perfect.  The room is such a unique, intimate space for a small dinner party (comfortably seats up to 12 people).  They only book one private event per night, so the room was ours for the evening.  It was very clear that the staff knew what they were doing, and they are very knowledgeable when it comes to suggesting wine/beer pairings.  For appetizers, the deviled eggs were a hit and the charcuterie & cheese platters were generous with fantastic cheese selection.  For main entrées, the veal schnitzel topped with a sunny side egg was the biggest seller in our group.  When our main entrées arrived, Barbara (the original owner's granddaughter) joined to tells us about the tavern's history.  Such a cool piece of Chicago history!

17.description: Wonderful food but the service was a disaster. We came in after the wells street art fair and there was one server and one bartender. We sat ourselves and managed to order but they were clearly understaffed. Our waitress did the best she could but the bartender in charge was surly and by the end of the night, multiple tables walked out without being served. I really enjoyed our food but the service was so bad I likely would not return.

10.description: Hidden gem in Old Town! Great cocktails, wide beer selection, and a variety of meat. Get the burger... one of the most underrated ones in the city. Very good upscale tavern without loud, blaring TVs everywhere.

5.description: Glunz is a very charming bar/restaurant with great drinks. The menu is unique and the food is incredible! There is a spacious outdoor patio and the inside is cozy, yet has a fun vibe. We came on Friday night with live acoustic music. Definitely put Glunz on your list if you are in Old Town!

3.description: Housed in one of the first brick buildings built in Chicago after the fire, the building is awash in original detail and/or historic artifacts. Built in 1883, from the original tin ceilings, wood floors, imported German stained glass windows and other fun stuff, the place has the authentic cham of yesteryear Chicago while being a comfortable, contemporary community treasure.Tuesday is half price wine night. Oh and BTW, the family owned House of Glunz Wine shop, also a treasure, is the oldest continually operating spirit house in the nation, so they have a great selection of interesting and reasonably priced wine (and beer).The food blew us away. Best described as a contemporary twist on classic German food as well as some hearty salad and fish options, everything, and I mean everything, was sensational. The food had a real authentic home style taste that only pride, talent and slow cooking can achieve.We had the roasted brussel sprouts, a beet, goat cheese, pistachio and caraway seed salad, sauteed red sauerkraut, and s salmon vegetable fish dish that were as home style delicious as it comes.The home made strudel was the final blew that brought the much sought gustatory orgasm we all desperately seek in our dining experiences.My final bit of advise, listen to Stephanie and order whatever she says. She's delightful and knows her stuff.

35.description: Do you consider yourself a person with good taste? Do you like awesome people? Are you awesome? Does delicious, succulent, killer food make you close your eyes and feel God? Do you like a strong old man cocktail? Are you into good stories and historical, magical ambiance? Well if you are and if you do, GET YOUR SWEET BUTT TO GLUNZ.

19.description: The Gluntz Tavern is a great place to go for drinks.  They also have an extensive beer list, including Leffe, which I appreciate as it's one of my favorites.They are always consistent in their service - top-notch - and are friendly, helpful without being overwhelming.  There is no bad seat in the house and the ambiance makes this place a complete package - tin ceilings, original bar.Classy but not stuffy.

28.description: Housed in one of the first brick buildings built in Chicago after the fire, the building is awash in original detail and/or historic artifacts. Built in 1883, from the original tin ceilings, wood floors, imported German stained glass windows and other fun stuff, the place has the authentic cham of yesteryear Chicago while being a comfortable, contemporary community treasure.Tuesday is half price wine night. Oh and BTW, the family owned House of Glunz Wine shop, also a treasure, is the oldest continually operating spirit house in the nation, so they have a great selection of interesting and reasonably priced wine (and beer).The food blew us away. Best described as a contemporary twist on classic German food as well as some hearty salad and fish options, everything, and I mean everything, was sensational. The food had a real authentic home style taste that only pride, talent and slow cooking can achieve.We had the roasted brussel sprouts, a beet, goat cheese, pistachio and caraway seed salad, sauteed red sauerkraut, and s salmon vegetable fish dish that were as home style delicious as it comes.The home made strudel was the final blew that brought the much sought gustatory orgasm we all desperately seek in our dining experiences.My final bit of advise, listen to Stephanie and order whatever she says. She's delightful and knows her stuff.

45.description: This is an example of a place with great service, delightful cocktails, and a cozy interior that serves up German comfort foods, but the pricing is outrageous. $11 for the beet salad, which consisted of 6 small slices of beets hidden in about 3 cups of over-dressed greens mix. $25 schnitzel, while delicious and a big portion, is in my opinion outside the price range for a working man's food. The steamed mussels and chorizo is a star dish here, but the 20 small and delicate mussels won't do too much to quell the hunger. After spending almost $100 (including tip and tax) for 2 beers, 1 cocktail, 1 entree to split, and 2 apps, I just don't have the money to dine here another time, or rather would take that money to somewhere with bigger and better portions or much better food. I would've given it 2 stars, indicating I've experienced (much) better, but since it is merely that the prices are too high for decent food, 3 stars it is.

33.description: The food was ok, not great. Very heavy, salty. We were enticed by a little blurb on Eater Chicago, which mentioned a special deal-- of which the waitress knew nothing when we arrived. The space itself was charming, with many original features.

43.description: I had attended a wine tasting at House of Glunz several years ago and really enjoyed the experience.  I had been meaning to try The Glunz Tavern ever since it opened and had the opportunity on a sunny Saturday.My best mate and I stopped in around 5:30pm and as expected it was pretty empty, save for a gaggle of boozy cougars who apparently thought my stylin' companion and I were musicians.  Not quite accurate, but I'll take it as a compliment despite their inebriated state.All the bartenders were very friendly, informative, and Colin was full of entertaining stories of the supernatural kind.Drinks were amazing and they really take care to make them right.  I had more than a couple mouth-puckering sidecars.We felt a bit peckish and ordered the cheeseboard: Three wonderful cheeses, nuts n' jelly, and perfect grilled bread.  Perfect, delectable snack.I'll definitely return!

2.description: An amazing "old school" bar from the Glunz family with a great dinner menu and wine offerings as well.  I had a chance to speak with one of the partners while visiting and was really impressed by how much thought they have put into every single detail!  Great service as well.  Don't miss it.

18.description: I met with a coworker for dinner, drinks, and non-work conversations. Two out of three isn't bad because we ended up talking about work 80% of the time. Anyway, I've been wanting try this place after seeing it on my way out of Plum Market. My coworker had never heard of it. It was great place for a last minute decision and for not having reservations on a Friday night. I can't say that happens all the time, but it was just our luck. We started off with the cheese platter and the french fries. My friend also got an order of the pretzel, which was bigger than the ones you get at a sporting event. In fact on our check, it even said "pretzel, huge". Insert your jokes here. For my entree, I ordered the gnocchi with roast beef and egg. I've been on this kick lately for ordering a meal with an egg - not sure what that's about. It wasn't a big portion (think small plates) but after chowing down on the fries and cheese and downing a glass of Malbec, I wasn't too disappointed in it. I enjoyed it and probably would get it again. Also, the entrance is right before the liquor store (if you're facing north) next door. I walked past it thinking it was part of the dining area and not the actual entry door. Duh.

41.description: The burger had potential to be great, but both the bun and beef were extremely over-cooked, to the point it was actually burnt. Had to cut off the burnt areas just to make it edible.

52.description: We were walking through old town having not been before and decided to stop for a few drinks. The refinery was empty, the old town burger saloon looked so so, and gluntz was pretty empty but charming looking. Boy did we make the right choice. The bartenders were amazing in how they crafted the drinks.  I had a rye Manhattan that while potent went down smooth as glass. The food was great as well, black truffle mayo with fries! We will definitely be going back again.

50.description: Like!This review is based on a November and december visit.Last Saturday I returned to Glunz for dinner. We ordered the pork chop, the sausage (brat+thuringer) plate and the ham and gruyere spaetzle.  That spaetzle with the creamy gruyere,  a smoky ham was the winner of the evening- perfect!I  also liked our entrees (although I like  my brats in beer, grilled with onions - the boiled prep at Glunz isn't my favorite).  Very good selection of brown spirits- they have the anchor steam Old Potrero which for me, can make a spot an instant destination...The staff is super friendly and fun which also makes the evening more enjoyable.  I rarely venture into Old Town but this bar is a good reason to do so. Note- the chef may want to consider adding the maple glazed nuts with pork back to the menu.  This was available the week of thanksgiving but was removed by 12/21.  That was a great bar snack!

4.description: One of my favorite brunch places in Old Town. The staff is friendly, the food is great, and I love the old school vibe.  The accompanying wine store is rated the best wine store in Chicago. My mommy likes it there. And my daddy likes the bourbon.  Me?  I like the scrambled eggs and milk.

6.description: Charming place that seemed a little "undiscovered" for a Saturday evening. Despite a few friends who prefer the more familiar (Americanized?) brats, they were outstanding. The German pretzels were the best we've ever had. Spaetzle a little more buttery than I'm accustomed, but still great. Roasted potatoes were toasted to perfection. And the strudel was spot-on and flakey. And to top everything off, excellent Austrian Meinl coffee (French press, no less). And for the bourbon snobs out there, Pappy Van Winkle (12, 15, 20 & 23-yr old).  Boom!Not that I want to have to book a reservation 6 weeks in advance, but this place deserves some serious love. Go support the current generation of Glunz family members and have a heck of a meal - and good time - in the process.

22.description: We come here almost every Sunday night. Wonderful food, and great service. An underrated gem.

15.description: Great tavern burger and amazing cocktails. Great atmosphere reminiscent of the 19 century when it was originally open.

57.description: Gorgeous old town bar with an olden-time look.  The beer selection is phenomenal and the staff is friendly.

20.description: One of my favorite brunch places in Old Town. The staff is friendly, the food is great, and I love the old school vibe.  The accompanying wine store is rated the best wine store in Chicago. My mommy likes it there. And my daddy likes the bourbon.  Me?  I like the scrambled eggs and milk.

36.description: Went to this place last night and I'm not exaggerating when I say I think I waited over twenty minutes for a draft beer. After waiting probably fifteen minutes, (after we had already waited a considerable amount of time to be acknowledged and given menus and had our drink orders taken) the rest of my table got their drinks and when I told the server I was still waiting for my beer he went back to the bar (I thought to get my beer) and continued running drinks to his other tables for several more minutes. The bummer part for the server is that I probably would have ordered at least three of those pretty expensive beers, but instead I had one. I thought the food was fine but the service was slow, unapologetic and unfriendly. Won't be going back.

14.description: Friendly place.  It's a 125 years place so it's must be good place to be open that long and survived prohibition.  Kitchen closes at 10.

58.description: So so pizza at a high price - this place is way overrated and the wait staff aren't that friendly - can't say I would recommend it - sorry

56.description: My dad hit me on parents weekend and my friends brought me here to cheer me up. Lot of hot guys and chicks. Drinks by Robyn are great. She's pretty cool. Dad. Let me come home.

29.description: The atmosphere was dope and that Pat pizza was everything. I'm avid about my pizza being cut Chicago style so I'll specify that next time ;)

42.description: As soon as you step foot into Happy Camper you're  greeted by a beautifully restored vintage Air-stream RV. Shortly after you realize that this isn't their only interior designing accomplishment but much more. The bar is surrounded with large tire swing chairs literally hanging from the ceiling.  The walls are covered top to bottom with some sort of rich oak wood. And they've had custom made neon lights highlighting the bar's rich Midwestern roots. Before even being seated you can tell Happy Camper has a  huge resemblance in their sister pizza joint, Homeslice. It feels like an Up North Michigan watering hole with a modern sports bar feel to it. Sounds weird but it works all too well. It's safe to say that the creators of Homeslice and Happy Camper know what's up when it comes to interior design and impressing their customers with looks but could the food be as good? I'll be honest I was a little skeptical with Happy Camper when I first read of the new restaurant idea. Not because I didn't think the food was going to be good but this restaurant location has been the home to past disasters like The Refinery which couldn't gain traction. Well that skepticism went out the door quickly when we received our Bloody Mary's which were garnished with a pepperoni pizza slice. Obviously being obsessed with Bloody's and their unique garnishes this was something new to me. I'm always looking for that distinctive taste or garnish to set Bloody Mary's apart and they've succeeded here. The food was also pretty tasty which included great brunch menu items like breakfast pizza, brunch calzone, chicken and waffles, and pork hash. I'd say my favorite was their new chicken and waffle item which came with a homemade honey butter that served more of a dipping sauce than anything. I'd have to give Happy Camper a double thumbs up. This camper they've parked in Old Town is here to stay. If you're in the area and craving some pizza or a beer I highly recommend stopping by. Cheers!From my Blog:bestbloodymaryblog.com

23.description: This place is cool if you're 23, single and like mediocre pizza. We waited about two hours for a table. The decor and camper theme are cute, and the waitstaff dressed in flannel makes this place casual. But the pizza is ok. We ordered the Peter (my favorite), Tony, Gaurav and a plain cheese. The topping combinations are unique, but the pizza came out warm and just reminds me of Chuck E Cheese. I'm also from Chicago so I like A LOT of cheese on my pizza, not some measly crumbles. I believe people come here for the bar scene and pizza is a second priority. At least our waiter was cute. ;)

47.description: Sat at the bar at this wonderful spot down the street from me. Great old fashioned's. Eric was our guy and took great care of us. The girls were fun and very attentive. Think I found a new local go-to.

8.description: LOVED THIS PLACE! The only reason it's not 5 stars was that the service was slow and the wait was a bit long.  Otherwise I can't wait to go back! The pizza was WONDERFUL and really well priced for what you get.  The appetizers are a good sized portion (try the goat cheese bread sticks!!!!) and really quality.  This is basically what CPK dreams of being but doesn't achieve (and what Stella Barra thinks they are but aren't).  Be prepared to wait, but it's in Old Town so worst case you can run next door and grab some beers until they text you that your table is ready. Thanks for coming to town, Happy Camper!

31.description: Solid 3.5 stars with strong potential for 5 stars. The Good:-Ambiance & Decor - I like how they utilized old campers through out to go with the theme of the place. One booth was actually inside a camper and they utilized another as the hostess stand and a DJ booth. Lunch boxes at each table containing all the napkins, sriracha, and silverware you need to get yo' grub on. Sweet neon sign of the great lakes!-TVs to catch any games going onThe Bad:-The Matt pizza (a meat lovers delight with canadian bacon, pepperoni, and italian sausage) we ordered was really greasy. Although tasty, it was way too greasy for my liking.-$0.50 extra charge for any additional condiments we asked for without any warning. We had a salad and asked for additional ranch and my buddy asked for additional peppers and marinara sauce to go with his calzone. Overall I'd be back more so for how cool of a bar it is. Hopefully the food catches up to it's looks. 'Til next time, cheers!

34.description: Great pizza, have being here twice and both pizzas were most excellent. Vibrant and diverse atmosphere

16.description: Friendly staff, not at all snobby, great food.  Feels very homey.  Really good beer selection on tap.  If you want to enjoy a casual and happy evening, you can't go wrong with this place.  Great music played too.

13.description: This place is cool if you're 23, single and like mediocre pizza. We waited about two hours for a table. The decor and camper theme are cute, and the waitstaff dressed in flannel makes this place casual. But the pizza is ok. We ordered the Peter (my favorite), Tony, Gaurav and a plain cheese. The topping combinations are unique, but the pizza came out warm and just reminds me of Chuck E Cheese. I'm also from Chicago so I like A LOT of cheese on my pizza, not some measly crumbles. I believe people come here for the bar scene and pizza is a second priority. At least our waiter was cute. ;)

11.description: WOW this place has everything one could want/need in a bar! Security, neon wall art as a map, cool layout (camper INSIDE the bar on the right, awesome for parties of 10-20), and tire swings at a 2nd bar attached. Open until 2am!!Liked that there was security at the door and the layout was open and the lighting/mood was perfect for a Sunday nightcap with my family. I was in from Brooklyn, NY and was blown away by Josh's 2nd effort in the Chicago eating scene. What an awesome, dynamic establishment for Old Town and us all!Mouthwatering pizzas (the MATT) and delicious drinks (TRAILER PARK COCKTAIL & PINK FLAMINGO) are reasonably priced. I had a wonderful time at Happy Camper and can't wait to be back for some of the live music!

39.description: Good spot for beer and to watch games but average at best pizza.  First they have too many ingredients which makes pizza soggy.  I've had 3 of their pizzas and all tasted like DiGirono pizza.

37.description: Back bar has serious sewage smell. I wanted a dirty martini...worst one ever! However I know better than to order a martini in any place other than a steak restaurant. My bad. Fun swings. Bring your nose plugs. Its bad!!!!

0.description: If you can get in..... It's amazing. I've been multiple times and the pizza is just to die for. I believe it's owned by the same people as Home Slice. All the pizzas are named after the investors who started the place. Good cocktails, decent wine and beer list. Really cool interior. There are a couple of partial 'campers'... One that you can rent out for bigger parties and one that the hosts and servers use. There is a side room that's only open on the weekends and they have another bar and a couple of tire swing seats. Biggest thing is the crowd... Go on a week day on the earlier side if you don't want to wait.

38.description: The food was great which is the only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars. After waiting for an hour and 15 minutes after a quoted 30-45 minute wait, the service was terrible. Every time our waiter was at any of the table around us he started off with "I'm sorry." Forgot our drinks. Took forever to run our credit card. Never came to check on us until our pizza was gone. Terrible service especially for a waiter that had 5 tables. Our food came out fast which tells me the wait is for the bad service not the kitchen.

51.description: Glad this little pizza joint decided to join us in Old Town.  While I haven't been back since just after they opened I'm hoping this place continues to stay busy.  And I can't imagine it wont.  Great vibe and decor.  Um...hello childhood tire swing at the bar!  Yea, you know the 10 year old in you is loving that.  Great cocktails and beer selection with pizza to boot.  Pizza wasn't quite as good as Homeslice but I'm hoping that it will continue to improve as time move on.  I'm sure I'll be watch countless games at this joint just steps from my door.

27.description: Gluten free friends!! I have found the best gluten free pizza in Chicago. FYI This place is owned by home slice, the gluten free pizza tastes the same.  My friends even tried it and they said it tasted like regular pizza. Honestly I would skip the flamingo drink. It's too tart and it's not strong enough. They have Omission gluten free beer that's a better option. The decor is cute, I went on a Sunday and it was pretty dead. Which was nice .

32.description: Im going to forego the usual "such a cool space!" (In this case, it was) and just get to he point. A few things to note:Do not add the extra chicken on your salad for $3. It is a ripoff.Management: If you're going to offer a kale salad, you really need to massage it before serving or it will be extremely tough. Such was the case.Be wary that they charge for sauces. Which is petty. $.50 for ranch. They ID check.  Otherwise, cool decor, decent pizza.

54.description: Went here on the Saturday after they opened and wasn't that impressed. It's a great addition to the old town neighborhood since it's a big space and has some unique seating and drinks. Had a 15 minute wait and were able to get drinks at the bar while we waited.I liked the decor, the hostest camper was a nice touch and the camper in the back would be great with a group of friends. The pizzas sounded interesting and have some unique combinations but the actual pizzas weren't as good as homeslices. We got the Sesame soy salad which I enjoyed and made our own pizza which was good, not great. We also got the Tony (prosciutto, cream cheese, goat cheese) and it was just ehh.Id go back for drinks and try the goat cheese sticks and sit in the bar area or inside the camper.

48.description: MANDY was the best! Rockstar!!

44.description: Fabulous addition to Old Town!! Just what we needed was this friendly spot. Visited this place last Friday with some friends that were visiting from out of town. The place was definitely hopping. We put our name in for a table and they text you when your table is ready. We decided to wait at the bar so we could check out the scene. This place has a cool, hip, casual vibe to it. We had a drink and 15 min later our table was ready. Score!We tried a few apps that definitely hit the spot. The jalapeño app is so delicious and not spicy at all. They also have a great beer list.After that, we decided to belly up back to the bar side since we liked it so much. They were very welcoming here and even gave my friends and I these cool FREE beer koozies. I like to drink outdoors (when the weather permits) so I always love a free beer koozie. Thanks for the great hospitality Happy Camper. I look forward to coming back often as this place is on my street! Welcome to the hood :)

24.description: It was good, but not amazing. The decor is really cute, I liked the starry sky in the camper. The service was very good. I had the Guarav pizza. The toppings were tasty, but I was not impressed with the crust. It seemed too cardboardy.

7.description: Gluten free friends!! I have found the best gluten free pizza in Chicago. FYI This place is owned by home slice, the gluten free pizza tastes the same.  My friends even tried it and they said it tasted like regular pizza. Honestly I would skip the flamingo drink. It's too tart and it's not strong enough. They have Omission gluten free beer that's a better option. The decor is cute, I went on a Sunday and it was pretty dead. Which was nice .

49.description: Jen was a wonderful bartender. she helped us with our work outing and was very helpful and personable. Everyone at the event enjoyed her company and we will be coming back. Thanks for hiring such a wonderful employee!

40.description: Excellent pizza and elephant ears. New favorite pizza in the city. The dough is just perfect. I want to come back here often. Love the tv screens everywhere and wood-paneled walls. Cozy atmosphere.

53.description: Overall : 3.5. The place was hopping the weeks leading up to the grand opening. I was skeptical and dejected cuz it's just a bar that serves pizza. (Note: I like to avoid pizza because my office caters in pizza from the various chicago joints every 2 weeks and i'd prefer to skip the carbs if the food isn't spectacular....needless to say, i am sick of pizza) Anyhow I ended up here for a girls night (not my choice). 3 of us shared 3 small pizzas.Decor/ambiance = 5 stars...they have tire swings at the bar!Food = 3. It's just pizza. They are named after people who created the idea for ingredients in each. I liked certain toppings on certain pizzas.. like the creamy roasted garlic, and the tomato paste on another...but again it's just pizza with hand stretched pizza dough....not thin and crispy or stuffed or deep dish.Service = 4. it was fine...they did their jobs. they were not too helpful with suggestions. Overall, I may come here again because it's close to me and the vibe is energetic.

30.description: Friendly staff, not at all snobby, great food.  Feels very homey.  Really good beer selection on tap.  If you want to enjoy a casual and happy evening, you can't go wrong with this place.  Great music played too.

46.description: Nice atmosphere and cool decor. The doorman was pretty overwhelming, demanding ID's the second we opened the door. We sat at the bar, and the bartender was extremely unfriendly. She gave me a small pour of wine, and looked really bored whilst behind the bar. Pizza was good, but not amazing by any means. The sauce is a bit spicy, but the toppings were good! It's a big place that's always busy, but on a Sunday night it was easy to grab a seat. Expensive for shots of Jameson ($9 each) and pricey for a 14" pizza. 50 cents extra for a cup of ranch. I would go again for pizza, but leave the drinking part at home.

1.description: Happy Camper made me the happiest of campers. I love pizza, fun cocktails & great atmospheres. Happy Camper delivered on all accounts. When you walk in you feel instantly like you're home. The place feels familiar even on the first visit. With its Midwest theme and decor, their is much too love. The tire swings are a huge hit and a nice touch, same with the neon Great Lakes.This place is hopping on the weekends, if you're opposed to crowds I'd recommend coming on a weekday. For the cocktails we had a pitcher of Moscow mules and the Hooch, which is Cruzan Rum, Lemon, Mint & St. Germain. So delicious. I'm definitely trying the Pink Flamingo the next time I stop in. For food, you can't go wrong with the classic cheese breadsticks. We also had their rendition of jalapeño poppers called Homies. So good. Guys, there is BACON on them. Now to the pizza, Josh was my favorite, a barbecue pulled pork, pineapple and jalapeño pizza. This is what dreams are made of! We also had the Steve, a buffalo chicken pizza, and the Carmen which had tons of veggies and black beans. Both equally good. The only down fall are the bouncers that check the ID's. They're pretty rude. As long as you can get through that, Happy Camper is the perfect pizza place to be.

55.description: Awesome pizza place that Old Town desperately needed.  This place is ideal for any situation; watching football on Sundays, grabbing dinner with a date on Friday night (stay and hang for drinks, the bullet bar top is so creative), or just hang at the bar and order a small, solo pizza.  I've done all 3 since it opened a few weeks back.Homeslice's sister restaurant so I had high expectations for the food, drink, service and vibe.  Nothing disappointed and I'm happy to have a fun pizza place in my back yard.

9.description: Welcome to old town Happy Camper. The new sister restaurant to Lincoln Park hot spot, Homeslice. Came here for drinks and an app and the ambience is great. I don't fully understand why they have campers in the restaurant but they definitely stick to the theme. I tried the breadsticks with marinara/goat cheese and it was solid. I'll have to come back and try it for dinner but I'll probably wait until the hype dies down a little!

26.description: Cool industrial look, extremely unique. A tad loud and awkward seating for my liking, though.

25.description: I really liked this place. Three of us went on a Wednesday night for dinner. There was no wait, and the decor was cool.We ordered a 14" Linda pizza and 10" cheese, both on wheat crusts. Usually I'm all about the veggies, but the cheese pizza was awesome. I kinda wish we ordered a medium cheese and small veggie instead.Definitely order the cookie dough balls for dessert. They look funny, since they're rolled in Oreo crumbs, but are delicious. I was going to take a picture of them to post... But an Oreo colored ball doesn't look too exciting.My only criticism would be that it was sometimes hard to find our waitress.

12.description: Happy camper has it all!! Amazing food, awesome cocktails, inviting ambiance and great service.The Chris is my new favorite pizza- the meatball and giardiniera is a perfect combo!!The pink flamingo cocktail is delicious!

59.description: Great new spot on wells. Limited drafts, but menu very similar to homeslice. Cool vibe and great food. One of the few casual places to grab a bite to eat on Wells. Wait can get long later into the night, but you can always grab a beer and hang by the bar while you wait.

21.description: I had the cheesy breadsticks here and they were pretty good! If their cheesy sticks are pretty good then their pizzas are probably pretty good too. I'll have to come here for a meal next time. This place has a very social and fun environment. You can also sit in campers inside the restaurant which is a pretty cool concept. I would recommend this place :)

17.description: Really cool bar and great service. Pizza was pretty awful, soggy crust. Definitely go there for drinks and the atmosphere. I wouldn't recommend staying for the pizza.

10.description: Overall : 3.5. The place was hopping the weeks leading up to the grand opening. I was skeptical and dejected cuz it's just a bar that serves pizza. (Note: I like to avoid pizza because my office caters in pizza from the various chicago joints every 2 weeks and i'd prefer to skip the carbs if the food isn't spectacular....needless to say, i am sick of pizza) Anyhow I ended up here for a girls night (not my choice). 3 of us shared 3 small pizzas.Decor/ambiance = 5 stars...they have tire swings at the bar!Food = 3. It's just pizza. They are named after people who created the idea for ingredients in each. I liked certain toppings on certain pizzas.. like the creamy roasted garlic, and the tomato paste on another...but again it's just pizza with hand stretched pizza dough....not thin and crispy or stuffed or deep dish.Service = 4. it was fine...they did their jobs. they were not too helpful with suggestions. Overall, I may come here again because it's close to me and the vibe is energetic.

5.description: Solid 3.5 stars with strong potential for 5 stars. The Good:-Ambiance & Decor - I like how they utilized old campers through out to go with the theme of the place. One booth was actually inside a camper and they utilized another as the hostess stand and a DJ booth. Lunch boxes at each table containing all the napkins, sriracha, and silverware you need to get yo' grub on. Sweet neon sign of the great lakes!-TVs to catch any games going onThe Bad:-The Matt pizza (a meat lovers delight with canadian bacon, pepperoni, and italian sausage) we ordered was really greasy. Although tasty, it was way too greasy for my liking.-$0.50 extra charge for any additional condiments we asked for without any warning. We had a salad and asked for additional ranch and my buddy asked for additional peppers and marinara sauce to go with his calzone. Overall I'd be back more so for how cool of a bar it is. Hopefully the food catches up to it's looks. 'Til next time, cheers!

3.description: Basically Homeslice's Cool Younger Brother. And I mean that in a good way. The décor was spunky and fun--loved the neon sign "Pizza is My Porn," and also the tire swings around the bar!The menu is almost, if not the exact same as Homeslice, which isn't a bad thing. They have good food! I had the Wells Street salad and the Gaurav pizza, and both were delicious. A friend I was with ordered the Breakfast calzone, and oh my was it a beauty. It was giant, and stuffed to the brim with all things breakfast. Definitely going to be trying that next time. The bloodies are also the same as Homeslice, flavorful with a pepperoncini and slice of cold 'za on top.Highly recommend!

35.description: Great ambiance. The service was really good. They made a small mistake with my order, were upfront about it and proceeded to remake it for me to take home in addition to my leftovers, and they didn't charge me for my meal. It was above and beyond, but really appreciated and the right thing to do. The place is really busy, but they turn the tables pretty fast. We went for dinner, but it would be great for day drinking, watching games, or hanging out in a big group day or night.

19.description: We've been to Homeslice many times and decided to give Happy Camper a try.  We knew there would be a wait, so we went early to put our name in and walked around the neighborhood.  We were told 45mins-1hour and I think we got the text around the 30-35 minute mark.  The place definitely gets busy and crowded around certain areas inside.  I was happy we were seated at a table that was away from the crowded areas.  Our sever didn't give us much attention throughout the evening.  At times she was busy dancing around and sticking her tongue out at others.  My drink was served to me in a glass that was cracked from top to bottom and it took forever to get someone's attention about it.  The first drink I had was pretty watery, which was disappointing.  We ordered a salad and a medium pizza to share between the two of us.  The salad had way too much dressing on it.  Our pizza was as expected.  I really liked the decor here.  They have actual campers inside with tables.  I'm not in a rush to get back, but I wouldn't decline if someone else wanted to go.

28.description: Absolutely delicious!  We had the spinach salad and the Tony pizza which had the lightest crust ever.  Amazing...the Bloody Mary was incredible.  Great spot!

45.description: Such a great new spot on wells!!! Came for the Bears game on Sunday, many of seat options, great food, great drinks, fun atmosphere. Will definitely be back again, can't wait to make this our new hot spot! Love all the salad choices, and cheesey breadsticks are delicious.

33.description: The staff here knows what's up. That's refreshing when not only the front of the house but the bar staff, servers and busboys all have their shit together. Let alone the kitchen fires on time and to order - impressive guys. 5 stars

43.description: Not bad, not bad, not bad at all! Good pizza, in a neighborhood with lots of mainstream pizza joints! Happy Camper is a bit on pricier side for pizza, but tasty. Non-Chicago style pizza. Environment is always popping and can be tough to get in.

2.description: This place was worth the wait. I had been to Homeslice, the sister restaurant, multiple times and was constantly seeing Happy Camper come across my Instagram feed; so it quickly became a priority. The first time I tried to come here, it was a Friday night around 8pm and there was a THREE HOUR WAIT! I knew this place was popular but was not expecting a "west loop" wait time. A month later I tried again, anticipating the long wait, my friend and I got there at 6 and got seated right away! So anticipate either situation.The food was great though! We got the garlic roasted as an appetizer and the Matt pizza which were both outstanding! They also had a great beer selection! Well worth the wait.

18.description: I had the cheesy breadsticks here and they were pretty good! If their cheesy sticks are pretty good then their pizzas are probably pretty good too. I'll have to come here for a meal next time. This place has a very social and fun environment. You can also sit in campers inside the restaurant which is a pretty cool concept. I would recommend this place :)

41.description: my new fave pizza place in Chi! I've had pizza from Happy Camper twice - once in the restaurant and delivery once. it's been great both times! great atmosphere inside, really really good pizza and a fun vibe. will be ordering more!

52.description: GREAT!! We are truly HAPPY CAMPERS!!! This is a great place to get with friends and have a great time! The decor is very hip, and everyone is very welcoming as well! The food....wow, it is awesome as well! We started with potato skins as an app, and they were so good, they are loaded with pulled pork, bacon bits, cheddar cheese, sour cream, green onion, with a side of honey mustard....man! I would get these again in a heartbeat! If you are a pizza fanatic, this is the place for you! They have every kind of pizza available that your little heart desires! For our main selections, we had the Curt pepperoni,  italian sausage,mushrooms & marinara and the Chris meatball, giardiniera & marinara...AMAZEBALLS!!! So good and the giardiniera hit the spicy spot I longed for on our visit! The service was top notch, however I do have a small complaint, oh so small, almost negligible, while the restaurant staff is great, I noticed on many occasions there were runners that came by our table to check on us, but just basically looked at us, without offering to refill our drinks, I had to point it out to them, there were about 3 people that were just looking at our table without really doing anything. This was kinda weird, but by no means a deal killer....We will be back to Happy Camper very soon...put this in our dining rotation for sure!!!

50.description: WOW this place has everything one could want/need in a bar! Security, neon wall art as a map, cool layout (camper INSIDE the bar on the right, awesome for parties of 10-20), and tire swings at a 2nd bar attached. Open until 2am!!Liked that there was security at the door and the layout was open and the lighting/mood was perfect for a Sunday nightcap with my family. I was in from Brooklyn, NY and was blown away by Josh's 2nd effort in the Chicago eating scene. What an awesome, dynamic establishment for Old Town and us all!Mouthwatering pizzas (the MATT) and delicious drinks (TRAILER PARK COCKTAIL & PINK FLAMINGO) are reasonably priced. I had a wonderful time at Happy Camper and can't wait to be back for some of the live music!

4.description: Im going to forego the usual "such a cool space!" (In this case, it was) and just get to he point. A few things to note:Do not add the extra chicken on your salad for $3. It is a ripoff.Management: If you're going to offer a kale salad, you really need to massage it before serving or it will be extremely tough. Such was the case.Be wary that they charge for sauces. Which is petty. $.50 for ranch. They ID check.  Otherwise, cool decor, decent pizza.

6.description: Happy Camper makes me a happy camper (ba dum tss!) That's a drum sound...like at the end of a joke...I went to Happy Camper with a group of friends the other week on the second day they were open to the public...I believe it was a Tuesday. Our group started out as three people but quickly grew to five people, and they were very accommodating with seating and let us squeeze in extra seats at our table.This place is cuuuuuute. When you walk in, you immediately notice that the host stand is inside half of a camper. There is a huge neon sign of the Great Lakes on the wall, and there are two campers in the back of the venue that are decorated with lights that resemble stars. Just adorable.We were seated in the section closest to the neon Great Lakes sign, and I think I must've taken like 100 photos of it that all looked the same. Anyway...moving on...our server was very attentive throughout the night and gave us really great recommendations for pizza. My favorite was the Marti - sun-dried tomatoes, artichoke hearts, feta, garlic, and olive oil. OH MY GOD YUM. We all ordered personal sized pizzas (10") and shared. Shoot...I wish I could remember our server's name, because he was great. He was wearing flannel...although that probably doesn't narrow it down very much. I want to go back ASAP and try the goat stix, mozzarella bread stix, ALL THE STIX THEY HAVE TO OFFER and basically everything else on their menu.SIDENOTE: My friend and I tried to go to Happy Camper last Friday before seeing a show at UP Comedy Club down the street, and when she got there around 6:30pm it was PACKED. Like, she could barely get into the door - that's how many people were there. We ended up choosing another place for dinner, because I think we would've been 90 years old by the time they could seat us. I would recommend checking the place out during the week if you want to avoid super long wait times.

22.description: The buffalo chicken pizza is one of the most delicious pizzas I have ever tried anywhere. And I love pizza. It's not overly sauced with the buffalo but still super flavorful and just right. This has been one of my latest go-to orders but I also love the Peter and about 5 others ones I've had here, all tasty with flavorful toppings and a solid crust. Their blackened chicken topping is delicious so I imagine every pizza with that on it is a good choice. There are a lot of pizzas with sun dried tomatoes (which I like), so if you don't like those, that may limit your options. We've had most of the apps, which are ok, but not as great as the pizzas. And please note the mozzarella bread sticks are not mozzarella sticks, although I think they should add those to the menu personally. The sesame soy salad was good a few times but one time it came out missing several ingredients but I'm thinking that was an isolated incident. The staff and service are both excellent from host to wait staff to people taking take out orders by phone and in person. We live in the neighborhood and have already been 6 - 7 times and are so happy it's here! A great addition to the area!

15.description: Glad this little pizza joint decided to join us in Old Town.  While I haven't been back since just after they opened I'm hoping this place continues to stay busy.  And I can't imagine it wont.  Great vibe and decor.  Um...hello childhood tire swing at the bar!  Yea, you know the 10 year old in you is loving that.  Great cocktails and beer selection with pizza to boot.  Pizza wasn't quite as good as Homeslice but I'm hoping that it will continue to improve as time move on.  I'm sure I'll be watch countless games at this joint just steps from my door.

57.description: Went their with my girlfriend after hearing the hype. We liked homeslice so we thought we'd give it a try.We went in and it was PACKED. We gave our name (estimated 40 min wait) and were told we could grab a seat at the bar. We tried several beers, the best being the Revolution Fistmas. After about 30 minutes, we realized we could order a pizza at the bar (DURRRRRR). Cancelled the reservation after we ordered the 'za.We got the medium size pepperoni, mushroom, tomatoes, onion (named the Ken I think?) and we added giardiniera. It was so good. The crust was the best part. I actually liked this pizza better than Homeslice!

20.description: The breadstick are AMAZING. As for the pizza, we had the Tory pizza which was absolutely delicious. The service was great and the ambiance inviting. Overall, a wonderful experience. We will definitely be back!

36.description: Love this place! The pizza is amazing & atmosphere is super cute!!! Beer is really good. Great to grab a drink or just go & eat.

14.description: I really liked this place. Three of us went on a Wednesday night for dinner. There was no wait, and the decor was cool.We ordered a 14" Linda pizza and 10" cheese, both on wheat crusts. Usually I'm all about the veggies, but the cheese pizza was awesome. I kinda wish we ordered a medium cheese and small veggie instead.Definitely order the cookie dough balls for dessert. They look funny, since they're rolled in Oreo crumbs, but are delicious. I was going to take a picture of them to post... But an Oreo colored ball doesn't look too exciting.My only criticism would be that it was sometimes hard to find our waitress.

58.description: I live down the street so based upon proximity and the positive Yelp reviews I have given this place three shots.  Each time I have been disapointed with the food.  I tried sushi on the first two occassions and it was very bland compared to a lot of other places I have been to in the city.  This week I ordered a steak teriyaki Bento Box and my girlfriend got the hibachi shrimp thinking that maybe other things on the menu might be better.  Wrong.  We both commented that the only thing that was good was the miso soup.  I just can't understand why people rave about this place on Yelp.  I will say that the service is great and the ambiance is good in the restaurant.

56.description: Just received the takeout tempura bento from Shiso. You can order through Seamless, and it actually came fairly quickly, definitely ahead of schedule. Everything was packaged neatly and clean--no leaks or soggy paper bags here. The bento came with 3 delicious dumplings, 3 pieces of a Cali roll, salad, rice, and tempura--delicious, and huge! I will totally order from them again.

29.description: Service was very fast and courteous. Everything was delicious especially the spicy tuna maki, salmon yokisoba and spicy shrimp udon

42.description: Best sushi I have had in a long time! Chicago maki roll and Volcano were my favorites. Friendly service and the food came quick. Cute and warm atmosphere. It is BYOB (they serve liquor, too) but have a $3 corkage fee. Will definitely be back!

23.description: We really enjoyed our meal at Shiso.Started with the Spicy Miso Soup and the Shiso house salad.  Both were pretty good.  My soup came out a few minutes before her salad which was a bit annoying but it wasn't too big of a deal.Next we had the Crispy Calamari appetizer and our first roll was a special Mango Roll topped with Himachi they had that evening.  The Crispy Calamari was a good size appetizer for sharing.We followed up with the Spicy Tuna Roll, Shiso Signature Roll, and the Sears Tower Roll.The Special Maki rolls were really good.Next time around I'll probably stick with the Calamari and Sears Tower and then explore the menu a bit and try some new things.

47.description: This place could be in the running for best sushi in Old Town.  The fish was absolutely fresh and the cuts were delicious.  Even the yellowtail had been trimmed so it didn't have that unsightly and in my mind distasteful fatty layer.  BYOB or I guess you can buy your own as well.  I will come back regularly.

8.description: I visited Shiso for my birthday and it was great. They quickly accommodated six of us and serve us rather promptly. When they noticed we were taking advantage of the BYOB option, they brought over glasses for our beer. We were charged a $3 corkage fee for each person that was drinking but it was still a huge money saver. I got the rainbow roll and it was delicious, not very filling but that's sushi for you. I will definitely be visiting again with the BYOB option.

31.description: Awesome restaurant with well priced sushi. The service and hospitality of the employees makes this a great place for date nights or a night out with friends. Also byob is available, however they just started offering alcohol with a bar.

34.description: Delicious sushi and the nicest, most attentive staff. Very clean and reasonably priced.

16.description: I was brought here by the yelp reviews, but I got to say I am a little dissapointed. The fried calamari appetizer was delicious! Crispy and great sauce! When it comes to sushi it was average... It was missing this "yum" moment and I will definitely forget about it soon.

13.description: Hidden Jem of Chicago sushi! This is my absolute favorite place to go for sushi and its fairly close to me which is a huge plus. I'm not that adventurous with sushi but I still enjoy it none the less. I've tried various Maki rolls here and they are all wonderful! I recommend the dragon roll. The only sad part is that they have added a corkage fee- except for on Sundays.Shiso, I love you and I will be back again and again!

11.description: Tried this for the first time and it was not busy around that time. Affordable bento box prices and the katsu curry was the bomb

39.description: Truly one of the best sushi spots in the city. It's small and quaint, and really conveniently located a few blocks from the Sedgewick brown line stop. Prices are very reasonable and the menu has a little bit of everything (including some awesome supreme rolls). The calamari is perfect, and the wasabi mayo is crazy delicious. The sashimi is delicious and fresh, and all of the rolls I've tried have been great. Highly recommend!

37.description: How did this little gen escape me for all these years?  It's probably because Shiso, with it's unassuming facade sits a little off the beaten path on North Ave just a little west of Sedgewick.I actually drove right by the place and had to turn around and go back.  There is plenty of street parking right out front which makes this place a breeze to visit.  Another plus?  It's BYOB so you can enjoy your favorite beverage with no corkage fee.We went with about 8 people (make reservations as this place is small) and the team here did a great job with our large party. The sushi was fresh and delicious, the rolls were innovative (ask about what the chef's special is of the day and then order one of them) and the space is intimate and cute.And best of all?  The prices are reasonable.Next time you are looking for great sushi- really take a look . . .and you might find Shiso on North Ave.

0.description: I thought this was really good! We picked it because we were nearby tonight. Walked in and sat right now. You can BYOB for $3 per person but we just grabbed drinks there. Started with spicy miso soup, spicy edamame and some warm house sake. I'm not big on fancy rolls (see: sauces to mask worse quality fish) so we ordered the sashimi platter, hamachi scallion, Alaska (salmon avocado) roll and the roll that had tuna, white tuna, avocado, fish eggs on the special rolls - blanking on the name but yum!We ate it all and the quality was fresh, clean and tasty.
